searchDocs.title: 1. JavaScript Compression & Minification‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Do not compress, minify, or combine JavaScript files used by QA Advisor. Some optimization plugins or themes may interfere with tracking scripts by modifying or delaying their execution.  ‚úÖ Check your caching or optimization plugin settings ‚úÖ Disable JS minification or defer/async for QA Advisor scripts  For more technical background, see When jQuery is Deferred.

searchDocs.title: 2. PHP Memory Limit & Execution Time‚Äã
searchDocs.content: QA Advisor processes tracking data during daily aggregation, which can be memory-intensive on larger sites.  We recommend the following PHP settings:  memory_limit: 1024M or highermax_execution_time: 240 seconds or more  üí° These settings can usually be adjusted via php.ini, .htaccess, or your hosting control panel. If you're unsure, ask your hosting provider.

searchDocs.title: 3. Plugin & Theme Compatibility‚Äã
searchDocs.content: QA Advisor works with most major plugins and themes. However, we recommend:  Disabling JavaScript defer/async for critical scriptsEnsuring your caching plugin allows output from qa-heatmap-analyticsAvoiding duplication with other tracking tools that modify global events

searchDocs.title: 4. CDN & Server Migration‚Äã
searchDocs.content: If you're using a CDN (e.g., Cloudflare) or recently migrated your server:  Clear all caches (browser, plugin, CDN)Confirm that QA Advisor scripts are not blocked or delayedMake sure your server time zone is correct (used for data grouping)

searchDocs.title: 5. Optional: Confirm Script Output‚Äã
searchDocs.content: To verify that the tracking script is being correctly loaded:  Visit your website while not logged inRight-click and choose ‚ÄúView Page Source‚ÄùSearch the HTML for qahm or qahmz  If these strings are not found, the script may be blocked or not loading. Check for JavaScript errors or plugin conflicts.

searchDocs.title: How to Set the Monthly Data Limit‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Add the following line to your wp-config.php, preferably above the line that says /* That's all, stop editing! Happy publishing. */.  define( 'QAHM_LIMIT_PV_MONTH', 10000 ); // Replace 10000 with your desired monthly limit   The value must be an integer.Once the limit is reached, QA Advisor will stop collecting data until the start of the next month.

Incorrect values may affect data collection or overall site performance.The appropriate limit depends on your server‚Äôs performance and expected traffic volume.The default limit of 3,000 per month is a conservative value intended to help prevent server overload. However, this does not guarantee stable operation on all servers.

searchDocs.title: What Can Go Wrong‚Äã
searchDocs.content: If jquery.js is loaded with the defer attribute, it may delay jQuery's availability, causing the QA Advisor script to run before jQuery is ready. This can lead to:  Tracking data not being recorded ("no data")Heatmaps failing to display, even though page data existsJavaScript errors that may interfere with other plugins

searchDocs.title: How to Avoid This‚Äã
searchDocs.content: To ensure proper functionality, please consider one of the following approaches:  Do not apply defer to jQuery. This is the most reliable way to preserve the correct script order. Include QA Advisor‚Äôs tracking script as part of your defer queue, but after jQuery. For example, if you are managing defer behavior in functions.php, be sure to include QA Advisor's scripts (qa-heatmap-analytics/js) after jQuery in the defer list.  üí° Based on internal testing, deferring jQuery can prevent the QA Advisor tracking script from initializing correctly.

searchDocs.title: Summary‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Always ensure that jQuery is available before the QA Advisor tracking script runs. This prevents loss of data and ensures your heatmaps and analytics work as expected.

searchDocs.title: What is QAL (Query Assistant Language)?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: At the heart of the API is QAL (Query Assistant Language) ‚Äî a language that empowers data-driven assistants to freely manipulate data. QAL is not a flexible language like SQL; it's specifically designed for QA's column-oriented structure.  QAL Design Philosophy:  Explicit Paths: Clearly describe the data reference path (Material ‚Üí View ‚Üí Result)Deterministic: The same query always returns the same resultMinimal Specification: Minimal syntax that neither AI nor humans can misunderstand

searchDocs.title: QAL Basic Structure‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A QAL query consists of four elements:  materials: Specify the source data (materials)time: Explicitly specify the analysis period (relative specifications not allowed)make: Build intermediate views step by step from materialsresult: Specify the final view to return

searchDocs.title: A QAL Example‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Here's how you request page view aggregation for blog pages:  { "tracking_id": "your-site-id", "materials": [ { "name": "qa_pv_log" } ], "time": { "start": "2025-10-01T00:00:00", "end": "2025-10-31T00:00:00", "tz": "Asia/Tokyo" }, "make": { "blog_pages": { "from": ["qa_pv_log"], "filter": { "and": [ { "like": { "col": "qa_pv_log.url", "val": "%/blog/%" } }, { "eq": { "col": "qa_pv_log.device_type", "val": "smp" } } ] }, "keep": ["qa_pv_log.url", "qa_pv_log.title"], "calc": { "pageviews": "COUNT(qa_pv_log.pv_id)", "sessions": "COUNTUNIQUE(qa_pv_log.reader_id)" } } }, "result": { "use": "blog_pages", "sort": [{ "by": "pageviews", "dir": "desc" }], "limit": 10 } }   How This Query Works:  Retrieve data from October 2025 using the qa_pv_log materialFilter for data where URL contains "/blog/" and device type is mobile (smp)Aggregate page views and sessions by URLReturn top 10 results sorted by page views in descending order

searchDocs.title: 1. Explicit Time Specification‚Äã
searchDocs.content: QAL does not allow relative time specifications (like "yesterday" or "last week"). You must always specify concrete dates and times:  "time": { "start": "2025-10-01T00:00:00", "end": "2025-10-31T00:00:00", "tz": "Asia/Tokyo" }   This ensures that the same results are always obtained regardless of when the query is executed.

searchDocs.title: 2. Explicit Data Paths‚Äã
searchDocs.content: In QAL, you build the data flow step by step:  "make": { "step1": { "from": ["qa_pv_log"], "keep": ["qa_pv_log.url", "qa_pv_log.reader_id"], "filter": { "and": [ { "like": { "col": "qa_pv_log.url", "val": "%/blog/%" } } ] } }, "step2": { "from": ["step1"], "keep": ["step1.url"], "calc": { "sessions": "COUNTUNIQUE(step1.reader_id)" } } }

searchDocs.title: 3. Limited Aggregation Functions‚Äã
searchDocs.content: QAL supports only the following six aggregation functions:  COUNT(column) - Count rowsCOUNTUNIQUE(column) - Count unique valuesSUM(column) - Calculate sumAVERAGE(column) - Calculate averageMIN(column) - Get minimum valueMAX(column) - Get maximum value

searchDocs.title: 4. Fully Qualified Names‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Column names must always be specified in the format <material_name>.<column_name> or <view_name>.<column_name>:  "keep": ["qa_pv_log.url", "qa_pv_log.title"], "calc": { "pageviews": "COUNT(qa_pv_log.pv_id)" }

searchDocs.title: 1. Device Traffic Analysis‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Compare mobile and desktop traffic:  { "tracking_id": "your-site-id", "materials": [{ "name": "qa_pv_log" }], "time": { "start": "2025-10-01T00:00:00", "end": "2025-10-31T00:00:00", "tz": "Asia/Tokyo" }, "make": { "device_stats": { "from": ["qa_pv_log"], "keep": ["qa_pv_log.device_type"], "calc": { "sessions": "COUNTUNIQUE(qa_pv_log.reader_id)", "pageviews": "COUNT(qa_pv_log.pv_id)", "avg_time": "AVERAGE(qa_pv_log.page_msec)" } } }, "result": { "use": "device_stats" } }

searchDocs.title: 2. Campaign Performance Measurement‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Analyze performance by UTM campaign:  { "tracking_id": "your-site-id", "materials": [ { "name": "qa_pv_log" }, { "name": "qa_utm_campaigns" } ], "time": { "start": "2025-10-01T00:00:00", "end": "2025-10-31T00:00:00", "tz": "Asia/Tokyo" }, "make": { "campaign_performance": { "from": ["qa_pv_log"], "join": { "with": "qa_utm_campaigns", "on": [ { "left": "qa_pv_log.campaign_id", "right": "qa_utm_campaigns.campaign_id" } ], "if not match": "keep-left" }, "keep": ["qa_utm_campaigns.utm_campaign", "qa_utm_campaigns.utm_source"], "calc": { "sessions": "COUNTUNIQUE(qa_pv_log.reader_id)", "pageviews": "COUNT(qa_pv_log.pv_id)" } } }, "result": { "use": "campaign_performance", "sort": [{ "by": "sessions", "dir": "desc" }], "limit": 20 } }

searchDocs.title: 3. AI-Powered Insights‚Äã
searchDocs.content: By connecting QA Assistant to Claude via MCP (Model Context Protocol), you can analyze data in natural language:  You: Show me the blog posts that are getting the most organic traffic this month Claude: [Generates and executes QAL query] The top 5 posts by organic traffic are...   The AI assistant generates QAL and explains the results in natural language.

searchDocs.title: Response Formats‚Äã
searchDocs.content: The QAL API offers flexible data return formats:
